title: Brainstem Involvement: Hypothalamic/Thalamic Tumor
chief_complaint: I have been having trouble localizing sounds and difficulty hearing conversations when they are quiet. I also feel a fullness in my left ear that has recently gotten worse.

problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing difficulty; Left ear fullness; Bilateral motor symptoms (Right-sided instability, Left-sided weakness).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent dizziness (2 years), occipital headaches (3 years), right-sided motor instability, progressive left arm/leg weakness, left hand paresis, confusion, and memory loss.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty walking, trouble localizing sound, difficulty hearing low-intensity speech.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of auditory and neurological symptoms.

history.present_illness: The patient reports a multi-year history of neurological symptoms including right-sided motor instability, dizziness, and headaches. More recently, she developed progressive left-sided weakness, confusion, and memory loss. Auditory symptoms include localization deficits and left aural fullness.
history.otologic_history: Fullness sensation in the left ear for several years, recently increased in severity.
history.medical_psych_history: Working diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) was considered for several years but not confirmed.
history.prior_management: None reported for hearing; medical monitoring for suspected MS.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis of underlying cause of symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Moderate to severe bilaterally symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss. The loss slopes from mild in the low frequencies to severe in the high frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition scores bilaterally, despite the sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present at normal levels (reduced sensation levels at mid and high frequencies) bilaterally for frequencies 500 through 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Essentially normal findings (Waves I, II, III present). Left ear: Normal waves I and II; Wave III delayed; Absence of IV-V complex.

tests.name: Auditory Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.key_findings: Generally noisy and poor responses. T3 electrode (left temporal) showed no repeatable response. T4 electrode (right temporal) showed response to right ear stimulation but nonreplicable response to left ear stimulation.

tests.name: Behavioral Central Auditory Tests
tests.key_findings: Left ear deficit on dichotic digits, competing sentences, and compressed speech tests. Bilaterally suppressed filtered speech scores.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a moderate-to-severe bilateral symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss with excellent speech recognition, likely presbycusic in origin. However, retrocochlear testing reveals significant central pathology. ABR is abnormal on the left (absent IV-V), and MLR is absent over the left temporal area. Behavioral central testing confirms a left-sided deficit (dichotic digits, competing sentences) and bilateral temporal processing issues (filtered speech). These findings are consistent with a lesion affecting the upper brainstem/thalamic pathways, specifically compromising the left medial geniculate body (MGB) and inferior colliculus (IC) areas.
counseling_points: Explain that the hearing sensitivity loss (audiogram) is likely age-related and not the primary cause of the localization and processing difficulties.
Discuss the abnormal findings on the brainstem and cortical responses (ABR/MLR) indicating a disruption in the neural pathways, particularly on the left side.
Urgent referral to neurology/neurosurgery for imaging (CT/MRI) due to suspected retrocochlear lesion (confirmed later as Glioblastoma Multiforme).
Counsel on communication strategies for central auditory processing deficits (visual cues, reducing background noise).
notes_for_actor: You are a 69-year-old woman who is confused and worried. You have been told you might have MS for years, but you aren't sure.
You have physical symptoms: you feel wobbly on your feet, and your left arm and leg feel weak.
Your hearing complaint is specific: you can hear sound, but you can't tell where it's coming from (localization), and you struggle to understand quiet conversations.
You feel a 'fullness' or pressure in your left ear.
